body:
The issue is on [this line](https://github.com/TheBricksThatHacked/DjangoAPI/blob/c784eddbc364cfb352634baa8e2101a502faea9b/bucket/appbucket/templates/profile.html#L85).

Is there a reason that we need to apply classes based on what the user enters? It seems to open the door for people to apply weird classes and for formatting problems.

Well the classes are used for the tag filtering function. It could be changed to be just in a data attribute on the element. There is no real security bug since django doesn't allow raw HTML to be parsed out without a `|safe` flag. Just potential formatting issues.

Good point about the security. I forgot about the `|safe` thing. 
I think we should change it, because I think from a usability sense it will be confusing if a user accidentally enters a tag that matches a bootstrap class name.

Switching to the data attribute is probably a smarter idea than just applying CSS classes anyway. I just did it that way because jQuery has a function `hasClass()` which makes it easier to implement. 

`data-tags="tag1 tag2 tag3"` and then checking for the substrings when filtering should work just fine.
Awesome. I'm not familiar with the `data-tags` stuff. That's pretty nice.
Thanks for the report, @mdw7326.

So I have part of this working, but I can't make the tags respect it. The tags for private items will still display on the profile.

I also can't make the form work correctly. The "private" field isn't being saved.

It also makes badges kind of weird, but I guess we could always base them on only public items.

You can take a look at what I did on the [private-items](https://github.com/TheBricksThatHacked/DjangoAPI/tree/private-items) branch.

I believe I got it working now that the tags will only be for the items that are publicly available. 

I also had to explicitly save the Private vs Non Private on the form submission. I'm not sure if this is a django thing with checkboxes or have to do with our hardcoded forms.

I also fixed a bug that wouldn't show the checkbox as `checked` if it was supposed to be.

Nice.

I'm thinking that, related to this, we should separate the public and private items when you're looking at your own profile. That way, the user can tell what other people can see.

Perhaps an icon to say that it's private. Idk about splitting them up completely. 

On April 23, 2015 9:49:18 AM EDT, Corban Mailloux notifications@github.com wrote:

> Nice.
> 
> I'm thinking that, related to this, we should separate the public and
> private items when you're looking at your own profile. That way, the

Sent from my Android device with K-9 Mail. Please excuse my brevity.
That's probably a better idea.
Additionally, we may have to verify that user names will make valid URLs. We'd have to add some validation on the user names.

I made the URL and view changes on the [profile-by-username branch](https://github.com/TheBricksThatHacked/Bucketeer.me/tree/profile-by-username).

Now we just need to keep users' names from containing `@_+`, on top of Django's built-in rules.

(Mostly a note to self when Nginx gets changed)

`www` won't redirect to a profile, but simply to the main page. Maybe that should be added to the user name validation, or we could simply create a dummy user called `www`. Whatever.
Pretty cool idea. I like it

So this is done, minus the Nginx config. 
#Procrastination
Feel free to look over the changes. It just modifies the regex for the user field, and adds a validation to avoid names that would cause collisions.
I did the Nginx config, so I'm merging this into master and updating the server.
Closes issue #12.
Closed via PR #13.
Now live on the server. Check out: http://corban.bucketeer.me

There is a case that I didn't think of. Django usernames are case-sensitive, whereas URLs are not. 
So the user `Mruss3` and `mruss3` can both be valid, but the URL rule will always push to a lower-case version. 

This also means that users with capital letters will never be able to use the subdomain, even if there isn't a collision. 

I propose making it so all user names must be lowercase. Any objections?

We could always store usernames as the lowercase version so to the user it doesn't matter. 

On May 17, 2015 9:26:03 PM EDT, Corban Mailloux notifications@github.com wrote:

> There is a case that I didn't think of. Django usernames are
> case-sensitive, whereas URLs are not. 
> So the user `Mruss3` and `mruss3` can both be valid, but the URL rule
> will always push to a lower-case version. 
> 
> This also means that users with capital letters will never be able to
> use the subdomain, even if there isn't a collision. 
> 
> I propose making it so all user names must be lowercase. Any
> objections?

Sent from my Android device with K-9 Mail. Please excuse my brevity.
Valid, but then we have to make additional logic for everywhere that a username might be entered. What I had in mind was only allowing lower-case users.
I think that @Friss would love to fix this one. :P
@valbooth28 See #20. You are welcome to add comments and a different license there.
